Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = e^{tA}x\\), where \\(A\\) is a diagonalizable matrix with complex eigenvalues and \\(x\\) is an initial complex vector. We investigate the effect of applying a linear transformation \\(T(z) = Uz\\) at time \\(t = 0\\), where \\(U\\) is a unitary matrix.

If \\(T(z)\\) is applied initially to \\(x\\) so that the initial condition becomes \\(z_0 = Ux\\), then allowed to evolve under \\(\\dot{z} = Az\\) without further intervention, will \\(z(T)\\) at time \\(T\\) equal \\(e^{TA}x\\) when calculated without the application of \\(T\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\(T(z) = Uz\\) changes the initial state, which affects the entire evolution of the system under \\(\\dot{z} = Az\\). Since \\(U\\) is unitary, it preserves the norm but can modify eigenvector directions, thus leading to a different endpoint \\(z(T)\\) compared to just evolving \\(x\\) under \\(\\dot{z} = Az\\).
